#‚Äã531 ‚Äî November 12, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Happy Birthday, Go! Go Turns 15 ‚Äî Grab a slice of cake, Go has celebrated its latest anniversary. Austin reflects on what Go‚Äôs latest year has brought to the language and what the ongoing priorities for the core team¬†are.

Austin Clements

Proposal: Add Region-Based Memory Management to Go ‚Äî If you have a long memory you might recall an indefinitely stalled proposal for adding memory arenas to Go. This new proposal comes up with a differently scoped alternative, based around regions, and has attracted a lot of comments both in support of and against the¬†idea.

Michael Knyszek

Polyglot Programming: TypeScript, Go, &¬†Rust ‚Äî A mind-bending tutorial journey about programming side-by-side in these three languages. This detailed video course shares how to get the most out of this multi-language approach, specifically by implementing a fully-unit tested CLI app and comparing the¬†differences.

Frontend Masters sponsor

üëÄ¬†wasmVision: A Way to Get Go-ing with Computer Vision ‚Äî Fresh from the genius behind TinyGo and GoCV comes a high-performance computer vision processing engine you can customize and extend with WebAssembly (which you can generate with TinyGo ‚Äì or Rust or C, if you're so¬†inclined).

The Hybrid Group

fmt.Sprintf vs String Concat ‚Äî While code using fmt.Sprintf might look better-structured, simple string concatenation (+) proves to be somewhat faster. Why? Max digs into how fmt.Sprintf works under the¬†hood.

Max Hoffman

IN BRIEF:

  • Go 1.23.3 has been released ‚Äì a very minor bugfix release. Fingers crossed we also get the decidedly euarithmous Go 1.23.4¬†next.

  • Matt Boyle has teamed up with JetBrains to offer a free, online Mastering Go with GoLand'¬†course. If you complete it, you even get a year's license,¬†apparently.

  • A mere tidbit from Julia Evans but if you haven't tried Go's cross-compiling support you might realize just how easy it is.

Go Runtime Finalizer and Keep Alive ‚Äî A look into Go‚Äôs runtime.SetFinalizer and runtime.KeepAlive APIs, two advanced features that have some interesting quirks and should be used cautiously. Finalizers are notoriously problematic (and may even be deprecated one day) while KeepAlive is easier to grok but will stop objects from being¬†collected.

Phuong Le (VictoriaMetrics)

Creating a 'Brainrot' Language Server in Go ‚Äî So-called ‚Äòbrainrot‚Äô is a mishmash of next generation slang and memes. Follow along with this tutorial as the rizzler Jitesh creates a bussin' basic LSP server ‚Äì no cap. Perhaps you can put the lessons learnt to more productive use? üòÖ

Jitesh Kumar Sahoo

ü§û And let's hope that's the first and last time we use Gen Alpha slang¬†here..

Machine Learning in Go with a Python Sidecar ‚Äî While Python currently holds the ML crown when it comes to the diversity of projects and examples, Go is a great ‚Äòglue‚Äô language for working with ML and LLMs and tying things together, even if it involves talking to Python-based¬†projects.

Eli Bendersky

üõ† Code & Tools

üïí¬†When 1.1: Natural Language Date/Time Parser ‚Äî A very long standing, and useful, library. The idea is simple: given a string like ‚Äútonight at 11:10 pm‚Äù or ‚Äúnext wednesday at 4:20 a.m‚Äù, you get the date/time you expect. Has rules for English, Portuguese, Chinese, Russian, and Dutch out of the¬†box.

Oleg Lebedev

html-to-markdown 2.1: Convert HTML to Markdown ‚Äî Actually parses HTML rather than just using regexes so can handle a lot of interesting edge cases. v2 is a total rewrite and boasts improved accuracy. It can be used both as a CLI tool or Go library. GitHub¬†repo.

Johannes Kaufmann

Reduce Your Apache Kafka Costs by 80+% ‚Äî Kafka with no local disks or interzone fees, zero ops auto-scaling and in your cloud with no cross-account¬†access.

WarpStream sponsor

Yokai: A Modular, Observable Go Framework for Backend Apps ‚Äî A modular framework for production-grade Go backends that handles observability, configuration, and dependency wiring out of the box, meaning less infrastructure boilerplate for you to¬†write.

Ankorstore

Miniflux 2.2.3: Minimalist and Opinionated Feed Reader ‚Äî So minimalist that no ORM or framework is used (just Postgres) and only the most essential JavaScript. GitHub¬†repo.

Fr√©d√©ric Guillot

üì∞¬†Classifieds

10x cheaper (and faster!) GitHub Actions with runs-on.com. Easily self-hosted on AWS. Perfect alternative to ARC or home-made¬†solutions.

Legacy permissions systems can‚Äôt keep up with AI. Meet SpiceDB, the modern authorization system inspired by Zanzibar, in Go and Open¬†Source.

  • üßã Bubble Tea 1.2 ‚Äì A popular Elm-inspired functional and stateful way to build terminal apps. Now with much faster¬†rendering.

  • k6 0.55 ‚Äì Modern Go + JavaScript-powered load testing tool. (Homepage.)

  • Task 3.40 ‚Äì Imagine if make were reimplemented in Go.¬†(Homepage.)

  • BadgerDB 4.4 ‚Äì Embeddable, fast pure-Go key-value¬†DB.

  • gRPC-Go 1.68 ‚Äì Go implementation of gRPC for HTTP/2 based¬†RPC.

  • errorx 1.2 ‚Äì Comprehensive error handling library.

#‚Äã532 ‚Äî November 19, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Mailpit: Go-Powered Email and SMTP Testing Tool ‚Äî A small, fast, efficient and zero-dependency email testing tool and API for developers. It acts as an SMTP server to which mail can be sent and provides a Web interface to read the mails. And being written in Go, it can be compiled to a single binary and put on whichever server you like. GitHub¬†repo.

Ralph Slooten

GoLand 2024.3 Released ‚Äî The popular (commercial) Go IDE gets its latest big update with multiline AI code completion, improved startup times for large projects, a way to look for cyclic imports, and a way to emulate a terminal in the output¬†console.

Ruslan Akhmetzianov (JetBrains)

Run GitHub Actions Up to 2x Faster at Half the¬†Cost ‚Äî Blacksmith runs your GitHub Actions substantially faster by running them on modern gaming CPUs. Integrating Blacksmith is a one-line code change. 100+ companies like Ashby, Superblocks, and Slope use Blacksmith to help developers merge code¬†faster.

Blacksmith sponsor

Understanding Command Injection Vulnerabilities in Go ‚Äî If you‚Äôre calling out to system utilities from your code, there are some basic yet essential precautions you can take to avoid security issues, because you certainly don‚Äôt want anyone being able to convince your server to run rm or¬†worse..

Liran Tal (Snyk)

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Developing a Terminal App in Go with Bubble Tea ‚Äî A well produced 50-minute screencast walking through the creation of a practical note-taking command line tool using Go and Charm‚Äôs Bubble Tea and Lip Gloss for structure, views, and¬†styling.

Package Main

IN BRIEF:

  • üî• Pyroscope's Go Playground lets you run Go code and immediately see a flame graph for¬†it.

  • üéß On the latest episode of the Go Time podcast, Anchor's Wesley Beary spoke about the challenges that arose when his team built a production-ready CLI tool in¬†Go.

  • üé§ Brian Kernighan, co-author of The Go Programming Language, ‚ñ∂Ô∏è¬†went on a podcast to discuss his new book Unix: A History and a Memoir and what it was like working at Bell Labs.

  • RIP to Thomas E. Kurtz, the inventor of the BASIC programming language, who has died aged 96. While not a direct influence on Go, BASIC had a pivotal role in bringing programming to the¬†masses.

  • ü§ñ Ollama is a popular Go app for running large language models locally. It's just had a major revamp with the addition of lots of Go-powered image processing routines to support Llama 3.2 Vision for doing things like OCR and Q&A against supplied¬†images.

Go sync.Once is Simple, But How Does It Work? ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe sync.Once is probably the easiest sync primitive to use, but there‚Äôs more under the hood than you might¬†think..‚Äù

Phuong Le

Encountering Hyrum's Law in Go ‚Äî When the author encountered an intriguing comment in Go‚Äôs codebase warning others to not change some text due to ‚ÄúHyrum‚Äôs Law‚Äù, he had to find out what it was all¬†about.

Abenezer Belachew

üìÑ Compiling a Go Program Into a Native Binary for Nintendo Switch ‚Äì Not new, but somehow I missed it at the time, but it‚Äôs interesting to see the¬†details. Hajime Hoshi (Ebitengine)

üìÑ The Go Module Proxy and Forcing Go to Actually Update Module Versions Chris Siebenmann

üìÑ Migrating from Prisma to sqlc for Better Performance Alexander Belanger

üõ† Code & Tools

Signls: A Non-Linear, Generative MIDI Sequencer ‚Äî If you like noodling with music, you‚Äôll enjoy this. It‚Äôs a Go-powered MIDI sequencer that runs in the terminal (cross-platform) and lets you create dynamic, generative music that evolves and changes over time. The author also created Sektron, a Go-powered MIDI step sequencer. GitHub¬†repo.

emprcl

WorkOS: Sell to Enterprises with a Few Lines of Code ‚Äî The modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead of¬†months.

WorkOS sponsor

Act: Run Your GitHub Actions Locally ‚Äî Run act and it looks at your repo‚Äôs GitHub Actions, uses Docker to grab the necessary images, and runs the tasks¬†locally.

Nektos

Git Town: Extra Commands for More Structured Git Usage ‚Äî Provides additional git commands to automate the creation, synchronization, shipping, and cleanup of branches. Compatible with popular workflows, mono-repos, and trunk-based development. GitHub¬†repo.

Git Town Team

gosax: Libary for XML SAX (Simple API for XML) Parsing ‚Äî A read-only XML parsing library focused on being ‚Äòefficient and¬†memory-conscious.‚Äô

Nao Yonashiro

  • Go Blueprint 0.9 ‚Äì Streamline the initialization of new Go¬†projects.

ü§ñ Control RAG access with SpiceDB's fine-grained permissions in Go and open¬†source.

Hookdeck: An alternative to Amazon API Gateway + Lambda + SQS. With local dev, debugging, and observability¬†built-in.

item.title: „ÄêTools for writing secure Go code„ÄëÁî®‰∫éÁºñÂÜôÂÆâÂÖ® Go ‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã530 ‚Äî November 5, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Writing Secure Go Code ‚Äî A handy article rounding up a variety of resources and techniques to keep in mind in order to write more robust and secure Go apps, including staying up to date with your Go version, leaning on Go‚Äôs tools like go vet, and scanning your code for known¬†vulnerabilities.

Jakub Jarosz

üó£Ô∏è This post also led to an extensive discussion on Hacker¬†News.

How to Compare Postgres EXPLAIN Plans & Tune Slow Queries ‚Äî Are slow Postgres queries impacting your Go app performance? Join this webinar to learn how to diagnose and tune them effectively. We'll use pganalyze to walk through how to compare plans & debug common scenarios like inefficient nested loops & missing¬†indexes.

pganalyze sponsor

Checking the Top 10 Million Web Sites with Go ‚Äî Actually titled ‚Äò27.6% of the Top 10 Million Sites are Dead‚Äô, I felt this is really more a look into using Go to do basic scraping at scale. Redis was coupled with Go (along with a lot of hardware) to perform the task in just ten minutes (~17k requests per second). The source has been made¬†public.

Tony Wang

Ranging Over Functions in Go 1.23 ‚Äî This post discusses several examples of using the new range-over functionality in 1.23, including simple linear iterators, recursive iterators, and a brief word on push vs pull¬†iteration.

Eli Bendersky

‚ñ∂¬†¬†The Business of Go ‚Äî I often skip high level talks to focus on technical ones, but Matt Boyle encouraged me to watch this, and it‚Äôs an interesting look at the processes of the Go team and how Go gets treated as a product, rather than just a language. Cameron demonstrates why Go continues to grow and thrive in a space where it‚Äôs easy for technologies to go¬†stale.

Cameron Balahan (Google)

Creating a Full-Stack App with Go and React ‚Äî A look at bringing together the best of the front end and back end into a single app, a contrived ‚ÄòGo Eats‚Äô food ordering¬†service.

Mukul Mantosh (JetBrains)

Constraints in Go ‚Äî John has finished his 4-part series on generics (which started here) with a look at placing constraints on¬†types.

John Arundel

Building Thread-Safe Abstractions in Java vs Go ‚Äî A look at translating pieces of the SimpleDB implementation from Java into Go, and differences between the concurrency and synchronization primitives the languages¬†provide.

Chris Rybicki

The First Newsletter Dedicated to Product Engineers ‚Äî Learn the skills and strategies the new generation of product engineers need to¬†succeed.

PostHog sponsor

üìÑ Writing Integration Tests for a Go CLI App ‚Äì A look at Luca‚Äôs reasonably simple approach involving make, golden files and table driven¬†tests. Luca Pette

üìÑ How to Build Smaller Container Images: Docker Multi-Stage Builds ‚Äì Including ‚ÄúHow NOT to organize a Go application‚Äôs¬†Dockerfile‚Äù. Ivan Velichko

üìÑ Why is Go's Compilation Speed So Fast? Wild Thorn

üõ† Code & Tools

vgt: The 'Missing Tool' for Visualizing Go Tests? ‚Äî A browser-based tool for visualizing Go test results ‚Äì described as being helpful for understanding the parallelism of tests along with identifying slow¬†ones.

Robert Laszczak

jsony: A 'Blazing Fast', Safe JSON Serialization Library ‚Äî Pure Go, reflection free, and faster than the stdlib approach, but you do have to lay everything out just¬†right.

Orsinium Labs

pg_flo: Stream, Transform, and Route Postgres Data in Real-time ‚Äî Offers a set of filters and transformations that can make moving data between, say, production and staging databases simple using one of two modes: copy-and-stream or stream-only. Uses NATS and Postgres‚Äôs¬†replication.

Shayon Mukherjee

Neotest: A Framework for Interacting with Tests from NeoVim ‚Äî If you‚Äôre a NeoVim user, this is for you. It‚Äôs written in Lua but neotest-golang extends it to support working with Go-based¬†tests.

R√≥n√°n Carrigan et al.

üì∞¬†Classifieds

Open Source Authorization: Zanzibar-inspired permissions, built for¬†Go.

How Google handles authorization at scale. A technical comparison of Google's Relationship-based authz system and Oso's Authz as a¬†Service.

ü™ùHookdeck: The Amazon EventBridge Alternative. Receive, authenticate, transform, filter, route, and send messages across your¬†EDAs.

  • ‚ò∏Ô∏é Watermill 1.4 ‚Äì Library for building message/event-driven apps: "Think of it like an HTTP router but for¬†messages."

  • üíã Charm Lip Gloss 1.0 ‚Äì Style definitions for nice terminal¬†layouts. An 'honorary' 1.0 release indicating the project is now¬†stable.

  • ü§ñ Gobot 2.4 ‚Äì The robotics / drones / IoT¬†framework. Now supporting newer versions of¬†Go.

  • sqlrange 1.0 ‚Äì Use Go 1.23's range functions with database/sql.

  • Slack Dumper 2.6 ‚Äì Generate Slack exports without admin¬†privileges.

  • Asynq 0.25 ‚Äì Reliable, efficient Redis-backed distributed task¬†queue.

  • fsnotify 1.8 ‚Äì Cross-platform file system notifications in¬†Go.

  • Ginkgo 2.21 ‚Äì Mature testing¬†framework.

item.title: „ÄêWhat's coming in Go 1.24„ÄëGo 1.24 ‰∏≠ÁöÑÊñ∞ÂäüËÉΩ
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã533 ‚Äî November 26, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

GoMLX: ML in Go without Python ‚Äî Eli recently wrote about Go‚Äôs suitability as a glue language for calling out to third party machine learning services and Python ‚Äòsidecars‚Äô, but could you just do the heavy lifting from Go itself? GoMLX provides one¬†option.

Eli Bendersky

üìä ¬†What's Coming in Go 1.24 ‚Äî A 52-slide deck that goes through language, tooling, and standard library changes coming to Go 1.24 (expected in January or February 2025). There‚Äôs quite a bit here, including generic type aliases, weak pointers, and an experimental test package for concurrent¬†code.

Daniel Mart√≠

üí° You may remember ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Daniel's similar talk about Go 1.22 a year ago ‚Äì when the video for the new talk lands, we'll link to¬†it.

Go! Unlock Your Tech Potential with Ardan Labs Consulting ‚Äî Struggling with skill gaps, development speed or complex tech challenges? Ardan Labs specializes in Go, Rust, Docker and K8s to accelerate your software development, optimize architecture, and manage tech debt. Let us supercharge your¬†team!

Ardan Labs Consulting sponsor

Are Go's Generics Simple or Incomplete? A Design Study ‚Äî Some argue that Go‚Äôs generic implementation only added complexity to the language, while others disagree. Nick takes us through a complex problem that he struggled to solve with generics, eventually ending up with a solution that works but felt a bit harder than necessary. Some commenters on Reddit felt that his approach was more OO / interface-based than it needed to be, though.

Nick Tobey (DoltHub)

‚ñ∂¬†¬†WASI to Go: Write Once, Go Anywhere ‚Äî A talk from the recent WASMCon event exploring Go‚Äôs relationship with WebAssembly and how WASM can help ‚ÄòGo go anywhere.‚Äô A pretty good primer on the topic as things currently¬†stand.

Zhou and Reddig

IN BRIEF:

  • üñºÔ∏è Preslav Rachev's ebook Generative Art in Go is half-off this¬†week.

  • Forget Go versus Rust, Go and Rust together make a great pair of languages to know, says John Arundel.

  • Matteo shows how a simple optimization sped up one of his dependencies "by¬†38147125738.8x."

Inside Bluesky‚Äôs Engineering Culture ‚Äî A writeup from May 2024 that‚Äôs perhaps become more relevant with Bluesky‚Äôs recent rapid ascent. Go sits at the heart of the social network‚Äôs¬†backend.

Gergely Orosz and Elin Nilsson

üìÑ A Go Production Performance Gotcha with GOMAXPROCS ‚Äì A well understood but oft encountered gotcha when GOMAXPROCS isn‚Äôt¬†set. Chris Battarbee

üìÑ Investigating a Memory Leak with Pprof ‚Äì Commonly trod ground, but well¬†explained. Aviv Zohari

üìÑ Testing with Go and Postgres using Ephemeral DBs Michael Stapelberg

üìÑ Getting a Pointer to a Constant in Go Xe Iaso

üõ† Code & Tools

superfile: A Terminal-Based File Manager App ‚Äî Built with Go and Bubble Tea, it combines a visually appealing design with the simplicity of terminal tools, providing a fresh, accessible approach to file¬†management.

Yorukot

‚ôªÔ∏é¬†recur: Retry a Command with Exponential Backoff and Jitter ‚Äî A Go-powered command line tool for retrying shell based commands in a controlled way until a condition (or success) is¬†met.

D. Bohdan

WorkOS: Sell to Enterprises with a Few Lines of Code ‚Äî The modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead of¬†months.

WorkOS sponsor

Porcupine 1.0: A Fast Linearizability Checker ‚Äî You write a spec for a system in Go, provide a concurrent history, and Porcupine figures out if the history is linearizable with respect to the spec. There‚Äôs a 2017 blog post that explains¬†more.

Anish Athalye

Sequin: Human-Readable ANSI Sequences ‚Äî The latest work from the folks at Charm (well known for Bubble Tea, Lip Gloss and other libraries) interprets ANSI sequences into something you can actually¬†understand..

Charm

‚öôÔ∏è nats-mutex: Distributed Lock Library using NATS JetStream Yurii Biurher

  • üïí Carbon 2.5 ‚Äì Developer friendly way to work with times and dates (examples).

  • Goose 3.23 ‚Äì Database migration tool. Supports SQL and Go¬†functions.

  • GoReleaser 2.4.8 ‚Äì Build/release binaries for multiple¬†platforms.

  • Mockery 2.49 ‚Äì Generate mock implementations of¬†interfaces.

  • Ginkgo 2.22 ‚Äì Mature testing¬†framework.

üì∞¬†Classifieds

üìö Risk mitigation is key to safeguarding your organization's future. Discover how Temporal enhances reliability and minimizes risk in¬†finserv.

üéÅ And a little bonus quote..

I saw this 2020 blog post by Brad Fitzpatrick the other day and liked an insight he shared about complexity and how Go changed his opinion of it:

"I used to tolerate and expect complexity. Working on Go the past 10 years has changed my perspective, though. I now value simplicity above almost all else and tolerate complexity only when it's well isolated, well documented, well tested, and necessary to make things simpler overall at other layers for most people."

___
Brad Fitzpatrick (Go team member 2010-2020)
